text: Today's meteorological term you never knew you needed: Isopleth

text: There were some people initially the other week who thought I made a typo when I wrote Part 21. No, really, Part 21, not Part 121.
author: ethanklapper

text: I don't believe there's a limit on ferry flights, they just have to apply for the permit under Part 21. My understanding is that might already be covered in some OpSpecs. Not hard to do regardless
author: ethanklapper

text: Hey folks, I'm deleting my other tweet as AFP has issued a correction to their previous alert. However, my thought stands: When this software update DOES get rolled out, it will just be the first step in getting the 737 MAX airworthy again.

text: Here's a good angle of attack (AOA) primer about how pilots use that information and what some of the indication options are. It's a tad dated, and by Boeing, but the information here checks out http://www.boeing.com/commercial/aeromagazine/aero_12/aoa.pdf …
author: ethanklapper

text: I'm not sure what happened in this NYT story but this makes absolutely no sense. Either the spokesperson misunderstood the reporter, vice versa, or both. But that's not an acceptable explanation. All pilots of course use lots of different data to fly https://www.nytimes.com/2019/03/21/business/boeing-safety-features-charge.html?action=click&module=Top%20Stories&pgtype=Homepage …
author: ethanklapper

text: I know one MAX pilot who had to go to sims due to local regulations. Everyone else I know did the iPad course
author: ethanklapper

text: Yes, it kind of ignores the underlying controversy of new type rating vs. differences training by bulletin (iPad)
author: ethanklapper

text: For example: If Airline A didn't purchase the extras, but conducted extra training on runaway trim, cutouts, MCAS, etc., that's good safety promotion. Airline A also has world class mx and had mx bulletins to pay close attention to AOA sensors. That's safety promotion. 4/
author: ethanklapper

text: It's not just one thing that leads to safety lapses, as Reason's swiss cheese model shows 3/
author: ethanklapper

text: Safety is a wholistic picture with safety management systems: safety promotion, safety assurance, safety risk management and safety policy. It's important that we don't judge a book by its cover. 2/
author: ethanklapper

text: An airline isn't more or less safe because of its purchasing decision on the 737 MAX AOA indication system. 1/
author: ethanklapper

text: In all honesty I think @jonostrower had the best explanation of the multiple ways of displaying this indication on the AvTalk podcast
author: ethanklapper

text: It's an AOA DISAGREE indication, not an alarm

author: ethanklapper

text:
Reminds me of Denny Fitch, who was a passenger (not a jumpseater) on United 232 when it crashed in 1989. Fitch offered his help — which was viewed as being pivotal for making the accident survivable for some.

Accepting all the help you can get is good crew resource management.
author: ethanklapper

text: I don't yet have a personal opinion of Steve Dickson but I can say that he's well known and liked in aviation circles and as qualified experience-wise as any recent FAA administrator
author: ethanklapper

text: It's official: Trump nominates Steve Dickson, formerly of Delta, to be FAA administrator
author: ethanklapper

text: Dickson was the SVP of flight ops at Delta, which is the organization that all of the airline's pilots report into. It's a role focused immensely on safety. Dickson himself is type-rated in the A320, 737, and 757/767
author: ethanklapper

text: New urgency to announce this nomination, to say the least. It comes with a 5-year term. Dickson's name was first reported by WSJ in November.
author: ethanklapper

text: I know on planes like the 777 that the doors also have a flight lock that engages over 80 knots. Not sure about your plane but yet another way the door can't be opened
author: ethanklapper

text: It's a conundrum because those older machines have little to no reuse value since they're a big power suck compared to newer SSD models. And like no resale value. I have a second generation MBP that I used for college collecting dust right now
author: ethanklapper

text: This is one of at least two uses for the AOC abbreviation that I know of in aviation. It's been a fun 12 months

text: As we learn more about #ET302, a good primer on flight control systems can be found in the FAA's Pilot’s Handbook of Aeronautical Knowledge (ch. 6: https://www.faa.gov/regulations_policies/handbooks_manuals/aviation/phak/media/08_phak_ch6.pdf …) and the Airplane Flying Handbook (ch. 4: https://www.faa.gov/regulations_policies/handbooks_manuals/aviation/airplane_handbook/media/06_afh_ch4.pdf …). Widely used by student pilots.
